paragraphs: Are you dreaming right now? How would you know?

During daytime, we are rarely confused about our state of mind: we are sure to be awake, and are (mostly) correct about this. During sleep, in contrast, we often fail in judging our own state of mind: even during the most bizarre dream scenario, we typically do not realize that we are dreaming.

The exception from this rule is the phenomenon of Lucid Dreaming: becoming fully aware of the current dream state during ongoing sleep. However, lucid dreaming is rare: half of humanity never experiences a lucid dream, and even those who do have lucid dreams rarely, in most cases less than once per month.

This rarity makes the science of lucid dreaming challenging: most studies include only a few participants, as researchers cannot afford to spend weeks at night in the sleep laboratory to wait for a lucid dream to occur.

While some people have lucid dreams on a more regular basis, either as a rare talent or through deliberate training, they typically cannot spend their nights for weeks or months in the sleep laboratory either - and only so many frequent lucid dreamers live close to a sleep research laboratory anyway.
However, recent innovations in neurotechnology allow to bring lucid dreaming research from the laboratory ‘into the wild’: wearable EEG headbands that record brain activity during sleep at home.

The International Study on Lucid Dreaming Expertise - or ISoLDE for short - aims to perform such research on the large scale: multiple research groups from six continents collaborate to investigate the brain activity of frequent lucid dreamers all across the world, thus creating the largest EEG dataset on lucid dreaming so far.

If you experience lucid dreams several times a week, please consider joining the study - you will have the opportunity to essentially contribute to the neuroscience of lucid dreaming, and also to join a vibrant community of lucid dreamers and researchers worldwide!

The study will include two groups of participants: the expert lucid dreamer group and a control group. All participants will complete a set of questionnaires. Throughout the study, participants will fill out a daily questionnaire on their experiences during the day and during sleep. Expert lucid dreamers further have the option to participate in detailed interviews.

Lucid dreaming experts will wear an EEG headband during sleep for a period of four weeks. When experiencing a lucid dream, they will signal this using eye movements. During the first week (control week), they will be instructed to refrain from LD induction. For the three weeks, participants will attempt to induce LD using their own methods of choice (or no induction strategies in case of frequent spontaneous lucid dreams).
The control group - individuals who have never experienced lucid dreaming - will wear the EEG device for one week.
If you are a frequent lucid dreamer and consider joining the study, please contact the research group closest to you!
If you are a researcher and consider joining the study consortium, please contact the study coordinators!

If during an ongoing dream you realize that you are actually dreaming, without waking up, you are experiencing a lucid dream. Sometimes lucid dreaming comes with a certain level of control over the dream content, or at least your own actions within the dream.

We’re looking for lucid dreaming enthusiasts who experience lucid dreams at least twice a week. If you’re passionate about exploring your dreams and want to contribute to scientific research, join us!

faq.header: Do I need to be able to control my dreams?
paragraphs: Proficient dream control is not necessary for this study, however there is one action during a dream you should be able to perform: moving your eyes from left to right repeatedly. It would be great if you would try this small exercise in your next lucid dream, to increase the chance to record helpful data.

faq.header: Am I allowed to actively induce lucid dreaming?
paragraphs: We are interested in getting a broad picture of lucid dreaming. If you are used to become lucid with specific induction strategies, this is of as much interest to us as spontaneous lucid dreaming. We would be grateful if you would document your strategies in detail!

faq.header: What is the goal of the study?
paragraphs: Due to its rarity, lucid dreaming is typically investigated in very small studies. With the ISoLDE project, we aim to create the largest EEG database on lucid dreaming so far. This database will be open for many research groups for different analyses. In addition to the EEG data, we are very interested in best practices of experienced lucid dreamers how to induce lucid dreams.

faq.header: Does lucid dreaming involve any risks?
paragraphs: There is no indication that spontaneous lucid dreaming poses any risk. Certain lucid dreaming induction strategies may pose some obvious risks, e.g. side effects of sleep deprivation, brain stimulation, or pharmaceuticals. Even purely behavioral strategies may also pose some less obvious risks: developing the habit of repeatedly questioning your reality during the day (is this a dream?) may exacerbate existing dissociative tendencies.

faq.header: Does the study involve any risks?
paragraphs: Participation in the study involves minimal risks. The non-invasive EEG recordings used are standard and safe procedures. However, individuals with light sleep may experience increased nighttime awakenings due to the presence of electrodes, which can occasionally cause mild skin irritation.
